elements.content: A new ligand, 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (DICN), has been synthesized by reacting 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile with imidazole in good yields. The cyanide group hydrolyzes to carboxylic acid under solvothermal conditions in the presence of different metal salts giving rise to carboxylate and imidazole bonded coordination polymers. Seven such polymers, {[Cd(DIBA)I]·H2O} n (1), {[Zn(DIBA)(MeCOO)]·H2O} n (2·H 2 O), {[Zn(DIBA)(NO3)]} n (3), {[Cu(DIBA)]·H2O} n (4), {[Ni(DIBA)2(H2O)2]·3H2O} n (5), {[Co(DIBA)(OH)]·H2O} n (6), and {[Pb2(DIBA)(OH)(NO3)]} n (7) (DIBA¯ = 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoate)), have been isolated. These polymers have been structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric (TGA), and elemental analysis. Both 1 and 2·H 2 O form honeycomb two-dimensional (2D) layer structures that stack on top of one another to form three-dimensional (3D) networks. 3 and 6 have the same (2,4,6) connected net, while 4 is a rare 3-connected net with a 3D network. Compounds 5 and 7 have one-dimensional (1D) and zigzag 2D polymeric structures, respectively. 2·H 2 O exhibits dynamic behavior through sliding of the 2D layers upon removal of solvent molecules in a single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) fashion. The Zn2+ and Cd2+ coordination polymers exhibit solid-state luminescence at RT. Variable temperature (2−300 K) magnetic susceptibility data on 5 are consistent with a weak ferromagnetically coupled 1D chain of Ni2+ ions. For 6, a spin-glass behavior with slow relaxation and frustration is inferred from the susceptibility data.

elements.content: A series of coordination polymers have been synthesized with the ligand 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoate (DIBA¯) under hydrothermal conditions via in situ cyanide functional group hydrolysis. A variety of conformations of DIBA¯ and flexibility of metal ions impart interesting frameworks as well as magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: A series of coordination polymers have been synthesized with the ligand 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoate (DIBA¯) under hydrothermal conditions via in situ cyanide functional group hydrolysis. A variety of conformations of DIBA¯ and flexibility of metal ions impart interesting frameworks as well as magnetic properties.

elements.content: Studies of coordination polymers are of considerable interest due to their fascinating network topologies and potential applications in storage, catalysis, molecular magnetism, recognition, and photoluminescence. The design possibilities of organic ligands and the coordination tendencies of metal ions besides crystallization conditions have led to a large number of open framework structures quite often endowed with novel structural features as well as unique properties. In particular, flexible coordination polymers sometimes retain crystallinity after structural transformation that includes shrinking, expanding, or sliding of layers in response to external stimuli. The stimuli can be in terms of removal/readmission of guest molecules, variation of temperature, and so on. In this way, they are distinct from rigid classical porous materials. The literature on imidazoles as possible donors to form coordination polymers has expanded rapidly in recent years. Frameworks built with only substituted imidazole as neutral donors will be cationic where the counteranions are trapped in the cavities. Introduction of anionic donors such as carboxylate can lead to neutral porous materials. Also, in situ generated donor groups via slow hydrolysis of precursor ligands under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions provide an excellent route of synthesizing coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Studies of coordination polymers are of considerable interest due to their fascinating network topologies and potential applications in storage, catalysis, molecular magnetism, recognition, and photoluminescence. The design possibilities of organic ligands and the coordination tendencies of metal ions besides crystallization conditions have led to a large number of open framework structures quite often endowed with novel structural features as well as unique properties. In particular, flexible coordination polymers sometimes retain crystallinity after structural transformation that includes shrinking, expanding, or sliding of layers in response to external stimuli. The stimuli can be in terms of removal/readmission of guest molecules, variation of temperature, and so on. In this way, they are distinct from rigid classical porous materials. The literature on imidazoles as possible donors to form coordination polymers has expanded rapidly in recent years. Frameworks built with only substituted imidazole as neutral donors will be cationic where the counteranions are trapped in the cavities. Introduction of anionic donors such as carboxylate can lead to neutral porous materials. Also, in situ generated donor groups via slow hydrolysis of precursor ligands under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions provide an excellent route of synthesizing coordination polymers.

elements.content: The carboxylate functional group has been extensively used for constructing polynuclear clusters and transmitting magnetic exchanges due to its versatile coordination modes, ability to generate metal−oxygen chains, and forming thermally stable compounds. Other bridging ligands such as imidazole, triazole, or tetrazole have a strong ability to form polynuclear compounds. Imidazole is also known to promote magnetic exchange between paramagnetic metal centers. Therefore, the combination of carboxylate and imidazole donor moieties in a ligand can potentially tune the magnetic exchange and lead to interesting magnetic properties. Considering all these, we have designed a new tripodal ligand incorporating two imidazole and one cyanide moieties at the terminals. The ligand (Scheme ) has two rotatable single C−N bond(s) that can potentially impart a variety of topological structures and a carboxylate group (generated under hydrothermal conditions) that helps to create neutral frameworks. Herein, syntheses of seven coordination polymers are described that are characterized and studied by different techniques.

elements.content: 3,5-Difluorobenzonitrile and metal salts were purchased from Aldrich and used as received. All solvents, imidazole, and K2CO3 were procured from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India. All solvents were purified prior to use following standard methods.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

3,5-Difluorobenzonitrile and metal salts were purchased from Aldrich and used as received. All solvents, imidazole, and K2CO3 were procured from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India. All solvents were purified prior to use following standard methods.

elements.content: Infrared spectra were recorded on Perkin-Elmer model 1320 spectrometer (KBr disk, 400−4000 cm−1). 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL-ECX 500 FT (500 and 125 MHz, respectively) instrument in DMSO-d 6 with Me4Si as the internal standard. Electrospray ionization (ESI)-mass spectra were recorded on a WATERS Q-TOF Premier mass spectrometer. X-ray powder patterns were obtained by Phillips PW 100 X-ray generator (CuKα radiation at a scan rate of 3°/min, 293 K), while thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was obtained by a Mettler Toledo thermal analyzer (heating rate of 5 °C/min). Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained using a CE-440 elemental analyzer (Exeter Analytical Inc.). Solid-state photoexcitation and emission spectra were collected on Varian Cary 5000 and Jobin Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrophotometers respectively at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Infrared spectra were recorded on Perkin-Elmer model 1320 spectrometer (KBr disk, 400-4000 cm-1). 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL-ECX 500 FT (500 and 125 MHz, respectively) instrument in DMSO-d 6 with Me4Si as the internal standard. Electrospray ionization (ESI)-mass spectra were recorded on a WATERS Q-TOF Premier mass spectrometer. X-ray powder patterns were obtained by Phillips PW 100 X-ray generator (CuKα radiation at a scan rate of 3°/min, 293 K), while thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was obtained by a Mettler Toledo thermal analyzer (heating rate of 5 °C/min). Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained using a CE-440 elemental analyzer (Exeter Analytical Inc.). Solid-state photoexcitation and emission spectra were collected on Varian Cary 5000 and Jobin Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrophotometers respectively at room temperature.

elements.content: Magnetic data were collected at the Unitat de Measures Magnètiques at the Universitat de Barcelona using crushed crystals of the samples on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer equipped with a 5 T magnet. The data were corrected for temperature independent paramagnetism (TIP), and the diamagnetic corrections were applied using Pascal’s constants; an experimental correction for the sample holder was also applied.

elements.content: To a solution of imidazole (20 mmol) in dry DMF (10 mL) was added anhydrous K2CO3 (22 mmol) with constant stirring at 100 °C. After 0.5 h, 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile was added at once and the reaction mixture was allowed to stir for 30 h maintaining the temperature at 100 °C. It was then allowed to cool to RT and poured into crushed ice water (150 mL) and the white solid separated was collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with cold water. The white solid was recrystallized from a mixture of DMF-MeOH solution to get the desired product in crystalline form. Yield, ∼60%. IR(KBr): 3447(br), 3125(m), 3123(w), 3093(m), 2920(w), 2232(m), 1601(s), 1500(s), 1403(w), 1299(m), 1253(s), 1108(w), 1074(s), 1013(m), 907(w), 883(m), 830(w), 811(m), 709(w), 741(m), 680(m), 650(m) cm−1. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6) δ (ppm): 8.47(s, 2H, ArH), 8.27(s, 1H, ArH), 8.18(s, 2H, ArH), 7.94(s, 2H, Arh), 7.13(s, 2H, ArH). 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6) δ (ppm): 139.10, 136.51, 130.77, 121.73, 118.65, 116.43, 114.59. ESI-MS (m/z): 236.076 (100%) [M + 1]+.

Anal. Calcd. for 6, C13H12N4O4Co: C, 44.97 ; H, 3.48; N, 16.13%. Found: C, 44.61; H, 3.59; N, 16.02%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3604(w), 3111(w), 1582(s), 1505.55(s), 1413(m), 1373(m), 1334(w), 1279(w), 1260(w), 1244(m), 1147(w), 1115(m), 1071(s), 1010(m), 935(m), 871(m), 815(m), 792(w), 755(m), 724(m), 659(m), 614(w).

Synthesis of {[Co(DIBA)(OH)]⋅H2O} n , (6)

A mixture of Co(OAc)2 (0.5 mmol), DICN (0.25 mmol), aqueous NaOH (0.2 mL, 2 N), EtOH (2 mL), and distilled water (4 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was heated at 180 °C for 4 days under autogenous pressure. After slow cooling to room temperature at 5 °C h-1, dark brown-colored block-shaped crystals of 6 were filtered off, washed with distilled water and ethanol, and dried in air (yield; 60% yield based on Co). Anal. Calcd. for 6, C13H12N4O4Co: C, 44.97 ; H, 3.48; N, 16.13%. Found: C, 44.61; H, 3.59; N, 16.02%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3604(w), 3111(w), 1582(s), 1505.55(s), 1413(m), 1373(m), 1334(w), 1279(w), 1260(w), 1244(m), 1147(w), 1115(m), 1071(s), 1010(m), 935(m), 871(m), 815(m), 792(w), 755(m), 724(m), 659(m), 614(w).

elements.content: A mixture of Pb(NO3)2·3H2O (0.5 mmol), DICN (0.25 mmol), aqueous NH3 (0.1 mL, 30%), EtOH (2 mL), and distilled water (4 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was heated at 180 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. After slow cooling to room temperature at 5 °C h−1, colorless rectangular block-shaped crystals of 7 in the wall of Teflon were obtained, washed with distilled water and ethanol, and dried in air (yield; 16% yield based on Pb). Anal. Calcd. for 7, C26H19N5O8Pb: C, 31.23 ; H, 1.91; N, 12.60%. Found: C, 31.39; H, 1.97; N, 12.53%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Pb2(DIBA)2(OH)(NO3)]} n , (7)

A mixture of Pb(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.5 mmol), DICN (0.25 mmol), aqueous NH3 (0.1 mL, 30%), EtOH (2 mL), and distilled water (4 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was heated at 180 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. After slow cooling to room temperature at 5 °C h-1, colorless rectangular block-shaped crystals of 7 in the wall of Teflon were obtained, washed with distilled water and ethanol, and dried in air (yield; 16% yield based on Pb). Anal. Calcd. for 7, C26H19N5O8Pb: C, 31.23 ; H, 1.91; N, 12.60%. Found: C, 31.39; H, 1.97; N, 12.53%.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray data were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation. Linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms, and the anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. Data integration and reduction were processed with SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction was applied to the collected reflections with SADABS using XPREP. The structure was solved by the direct method using SHELXTL and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 program package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were positioned geometrically and treated as riding atoms using SHELXL default parameters, while hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps and refined freely keeping the O−H bond distances constrained to ∼0.85 Å with the DFIX command. Atom C3, C13 in 6 and N1, N4, N9, C12, C13, C14, and C21 in 7 are refined isotropically. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table , while selected bond angles and distances are given in Table S1 ().
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structural Studies

Single crystal X-ray data were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation. Linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms, and the anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. Data integration and reduction were processed with SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction was applied to the collected reflections with SADABS using XPREP. The structure was solved by the direct method using SHELXTL and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 program package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were positioned geometrically and treated as riding atoms using SHELXL default parameters, while hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps and refined freely keeping the O-H bond distances constrained to ~0.85 Å with the DFIX command. Atom C3, C13 in 6 and N1, N4, N9, C12, C13, C14, and C21 in 7 are refined isotropically. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table , while selected bond angles and distances are given in Table S1 ().

The tripodal ligand 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (DICN) slowly hydrolyzes into the corresponding carboxylic acid 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid (DIBAH) under solvothermal conditions. Recently, Sun and co-workers reported a series of coordination polymers with DIBA¯ and showed the various conformations of this ligand. It has long been known that nitriles can be hydrolyzed to carboxylic acids and ammonia. In neutral conditions, the rate of this reaction is very slow, whereas under basic or acidic conditions and high temperatures, the rate of the reaction increases dramatically. Additionally, introduction of auxiliary N-donor imidazoles in the reaction system has a subtle influence on both complex formation and crystal packing. By judicious control of pH of the solutions to control the hydrolysis, seven coordination polymers with different metal ions have been successfully synthesized. The carboxylate group adopts different coordination modes in these structures and different conformations arise due to the C−N single bond rotations as illustrated in Scheme .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The tripodal ligand 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (DICN) slowly hydrolyzes into the corresponding carboxylic acid 3,5-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzoic acid (DIBAH) under solvothermal conditions. Recently, Sun and co-workers reported a series of coordination polymers with DIBA¯ and showed the various conformations of this ligand. It has long been known that nitriles can be hydrolyzed to carboxylic acids and ammonia. In neutral conditions, the rate of this reaction is very slow, whereas under basic or acidic conditions and high temperatures, the rate of the reaction increases dramatically. Additionally, introduction of auxiliary N-donor imidazoles in the reaction system has a subtle influence on both complex formation and crystal packing. By judicious control of pH of the solutions to control the hydrolysis, seven coordination polymers with different metal ions have been successfully synthesized. The carboxylate group adopts different coordination modes in these structures and different conformations arise due to the C-N single bond rotations as illustrated in Scheme .

elements.content: The ligand DICN shows the characteristic nitrile stretching at 2232 cm−1. This peak is absent in the coordination polymers (), and at the same time, each polymer exhibits a strong absorption band in the region, 1350−1550 cm−1 diagnostic of coordinated carboxylate.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit consists of one Cd2+, one DIBA¯ ligand, one coordinated iodide, and a lattice water. The metal ion adopts a slightly distorted square pyramidal geometry. The iodide ion occupies the axial position (Cd−I = 2.737 Å), while the equatorial positions are occupied by one chelating carboxylate (Cd−O = 2.281−2.456 Å) and two N of two imidazole rings (Cd−N = 2.251 Å and 2.266 Å) belong to three different DIBA¯ ligands (Figure and ). The structure assumes an infinite 2D honeycomb layered pattern where each metal ion sits 3.7 Å above the plane. These 2D layers are stacked one over the other in ···ABAB··· repeating fashion in the ab plane (Figure ) forming channels in the c-direction. These channels are occupied by water molecules that form hydrogen bonds with neighboring carboxylate oxygen (O1−OW1 = 2.918 Å). Examples of honeycomb layered structures are available in the literature with metals other than Cd2+.

Structure of {[Cd(DIBA)I]⋅H2O} n , (1)

The asymmetric unit consists of one Cd2+, one DIBA¯ ligand, one coordinated iodide, and a lattice water. The metal ion adopts a slightly distorted square pyramidal geometry. The iodide ion occupies the axial position (Cd-I = 2.737 Å), while the equatorial positions are occupied by one chelating carboxylate (Cd-O = 2.281-2.456 Å) and two N of two imidazole rings (Cd-N = 2.251 Å and 2.266 Å) belong to three different DIBA¯ ligands (Figure  and ). The structure assumes an infinite 2D honeycomb layered pattern where each metal ion sits 3.7 Å above the plane. These 2D layers are stacked one over the other in ⋅⋅⋅ABAB⋅⋅⋅ repeating fashion in the ab plane (Figure ) forming channels in the c-direction. These channels are occupied by water molecules that form hydrogen bonds with neighboring carboxylate oxygen (O1-OW1 = 2.918 Å). Examples of honeycomb layered structures are available in the literature with metals other than Cd2+.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit here consists of one Zn2+, one DIBA¯, one MeCOO¯, and a lattice water. The metal ion shows distorted tetrahedral geometry with coordination from one carboxylate O of one DIBA¯ (Zn−O = 1.959 Å), one carboxylate O of acetate (Zn−O = 1.953 Å), and two imidazole N of two other different DIBA¯ ligands (Zn−N = 2.012, 2.017 Å) (Figure ). Like 1, it also forms a 2D layer structure showing a honeycomb pattern where the layers are stacked on each other in ···ABAB··· fashion (Figure ).

elements.content: Water molecules are trapped in between layers with H-bonding interactions with the noncoordinated carboxylate O atoms (O···OW = 2.821−2.801 Å). This generates an overall 3D framework. The methyl groups of the coordinated acetate anions of one layer thread the layer above it. Also, strong π---π interactions exist between layers with a separation of ∼3.5 Å between mean planes of the aromatic rings (Figure ).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that the lattice water molecules can be removed easily at 100 °C and framework starts to decompose above 355 °C (). Interestingly, this framework exhibits dynamic behavior upon removal/readmission of the lattice water molecules maintaining crystallinity. When the structure of evacuated framework {[Zn(DIBA)(MeCOO)]} n , (2) obtained by heating 2·H 2 O at 100 °C under a vacuum for 2 h, is compared with 2·H 2 O, the local structure around the metal center does not change significantly (Zn−O, 1.934−1.956 Å; Zn−N, 1.982−2.052 Å compared to Zn−O = 1.953−1.959 Å; Zn−N = 2.012−2.017 Å in 2·H 2 O). Also, the overall connectivity in 2 remains the same. The important change that has taken place here is the rotation of the imidazole ring with respect to the benzene ring. The dihedral angles between the benzene and the imidazole rings are now 2.61 and 36.69° from the corresponding values of 28.58 and 35.44° in 2·H 2 O. Besides, as a result of breaking of hydrogen bonds with water molecules, the 2D layers slide on each other to stabilize itself by aromatic C−H···O interactions. Figure shows the difference between stacking of the two layers after dehydration as the position of the metal center in one layer moves far away from metal centers of adjacent layers in 2. The closest Zn(first layer)−Zn(second layer) distance in 2 is 5.960 Å, while it is 5.208 Å in 2·H 2 O. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the two compounds show considerable changes (). However, readmission of water molecules in 2 by exposing the crystals in the air for a few days regenerates the original structure 2·H 2 O, as confirmed by single crystal X-ray data. Such type of dynamic framework with layer sliding phenomenon is known in the literature.

elements.content: In this structure, the asymmetric unit consists of one Zn2+, one DIBA¯, and one NO3¯ (each with half occupancy). The coordination geometry around the metal ion is distorted octahedral with equatorial ligation from two carboxylate O and two imidazole N atoms from four different ligand moieties. The two axial sites are occupied by two nitrate O atoms (Figure ). The Zn−O distances with carboxylate and nitrate anions are 2.087 and 2.243 Å, respectively, while the Zn−N distance is 2.064 Å.

Structure of {[Zn(DIBA)(NO3)]} n , (3)

In this structure, the asymmetric unit consists of one Zn2+, one DIBA¯, and one NO3¯ (each with half occupancy). The coordination geometry around the metal ion is distorted octahedral with equatorial ligation from two carboxylate O and two imidazole N atoms from four different ligand moieties. The two axial sites are occupied by two nitrate O atoms (Figure ). The Zn-O distances with carboxylate and nitrate anions are 2.087 and 2.243 Å, respectively, while the Zn-N distance is 2.064 Å.

elements.content: Both the carboxylate and the nitrate act as bridging ligands between Zn2+ centers to generate a 1D chain along the crystallographic b-axis which is further connected with neighboring chains through imidazole arms to generate an overall 3D structure (Figure ). In order to understand the structure of 3 more clearly, topological analysis is carried out to simplify the framework. Each DIBA¯ ligand bridges four Zn2+ atoms, while every Zn2+ atom connects four DIBA¯ ligands and another two Zn2+ atoms. Also, nitrate bridges between two metal centers. So the nitrate, DIBA¯ ligand, and Zn2+ atom can be defined as 2-, 4-, and 6-connected nodes, respectively (Figure ). The Schläfli symbol for DIBA¯ nodes is 43.62.8, for Zn2+ nodes 44.62.88.10 and that for nitrate 4. Thereby, this (2,4,6)-connected net belongs to {43.62.8}{44.62.88.10}{4} topology.

elements.content: The structure of this compound reveals that Cu2+ has been reduced to Cu1+ under prevailing solvothermal conditions. The asymmetric unit consists of one Cu1+ with half occupancy, one DIBA¯ and one lattice water. The T-shaped Cu1+ is coordinated by two imidazoles (Cu−N = 1.908 and 1.910 Å) and one monodentate carboxylate O atom (Cu−O = 2.583 Å) (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Structure of {[Cu(DIBA)]⋅H2O} n , (4)

The structure of this compound reveals that Cu2+ has been reduced to Cu1+ under prevailing solvothermal conditions. The asymmetric unit consists of one Cu1+ with half occupancy, one DIBA¯ and one lattice water. The T-shaped Cu1+ is coordinated by two imidazoles (Cu-N = 1.908 and 1.910 Å) and one monodentate carboxylate O atom (Cu-O = 2.583 Å) (Figure ).

elements.content: Coordination environment around Cu ion in 4.
elements.clean_text: 9  Coordination environment around Cu ion in 4.

elements.content: All three aromatic rings in DIBA¯ in 4 are nearly coplanar, while the carboxylate moiety is twisted with respect to the aromatic rings showing a torsion angle of 36.15°. The coordination of imidazoles from two different ligand units with Cu1+ generates a one-dimensional rod-like chain along the b-axis, and the twisted carboxylate O atoms from another ligand unit binds two Cu1+ centers belong to two different rod-like structures (). The small cavities generated along the crystallographic c-axis are filled with water molecules (Figure ), forming H-bonds with coordinated carboxylate O (OW1−O1 = 2.804 Å). From the topological point of view and considering DIBA¯ and Cu1+ as 3-connected nodes as both are connected through three Cu1+ and three DIBA¯ ligands, the 3D framework of 4 is a uninodal (3,3)-connected net (Figure ), comprised of Cu1+ centers and ligands with the Schäfli symbol of (103)(103). This is a rare example of a 3D Cu(I) coordination polymer which is air-stable and has T-shaped metal centers.

elements.content: This compound forms a 1D coordination polymer where the carboxylate groups remain free. The asymmetric unit contains two Ni2+ ions with half occupancy, two DIBA¯, two coordinated water, and three lattice water molecules. Each metal shows distorted octahedral geometry with equatorial ligation from four imidazoles belonging to four different DIBA¯ ligands (Ni−N = 2.061−2.105 Å) and axial ligation from two water molecules (Ni−OW1 = 2.095) (Figure ). Two Ni2+ ions bonded by the two imidazoles of a DIBA¯ ligand are separated by a distance of 10.02 Å. By considering DIBA¯ and Ni2+ as 2- and 4-connected nodes as the carboxylate arm of DIBA¯ is free and Ni2+ is connected to four DIBA¯ ligands, 1D polymer of 5 is a (2,4)-connected net, comprised of Ni2+ centers and ligands.

Structure of {[Ni(DIBA)2(H2O)2]⋅3H2O} n , (5)

This compound forms a 1D coordination polymer where the carboxylate groups remain free. The asymmetric unit contains two Ni2+ ions with half occupancy, two DIBA¯, two coordinated water, and three lattice water molecules. Each metal shows distorted octahedral geometry with equatorial ligation from four imidazoles belonging to four different DIBA¯ ligands (Ni-N = 2.061-2.105 Å) and axial ligation from two water molecules (Ni-OW1 = 2.095) (Figure ). Two Ni2+ ions bonded by the two imidazoles of a DIBA¯ ligand are separated by a distance of 10.02 Å. By considering DIBA¯ and Ni2+ as 2- and 4-connected nodes as the carboxylate arm of DIBA¯ is free and Ni2+ is connected to four DIBA¯ ligands, 1D polymer of 5 is a (2,4)-connected net, comprised of Ni2+ centers and ligands.

elements.content:
The carboxylate O atoms form H-bonds with lattice as well as coordinated water molecules generating a H-bonded 3D framework (Figure ).

Figure illustrates the H-bonded network formed by the carboxylates and water molecules. The shortest distance for H-bond is 2.643 Å between O1 and OW1, while longest distance is 3.043 Å between O3 and OW1. The four free carboxylates shown in Figure come from four different 1D chains. There is also π---π interactions between arenes of two different DIBA¯ ligands (3.54 Å) of adjacent chains.

elements.content: The Co2+ ions are bridged by a syn,syn-carboxylato group and a bridging OH− (the shorter Co−O bond distance for both Co(1) and Co(2)) as shown in Figure , with a Co−O−Co angle of 127.06°, forming infinite 1D polymers along the a-axis (Figure a). The octahedra of the Co2+ ions are tilted, with an angle between the xy planes of the Co(1) and Co(2) ions of 43.98°. The 1D chains are linked by the tetradentate ligands, each ligand binds two Co(1) and two Co(2) ions. Of these, one Co(1) and one Co(2) are in turn bridged by a OH− forming a triangular 3D network of corner-sharing distorted tetrahedra, as shown in Figures and b.

elements.content: Structural analysis of 7 shows that there are two crystallographically independent Pb2+ centers: one pentacoordinated Pb(1) and the other, hexacoordinated Pb(2). Pb(1) is coordinated to one chelating carboxylate (Pb1−O = 2.547−2.564 Å) and two imidazoles (Pb1−N = 2.591−2.784 Å) from three different ligand moieties. The fifth coordination site is occupied by a hydroxyl group which acts as a bridge between Pb(1) and Pb(2) (Pb1−OH = 2.183, Pb2−OH = 2.199 Å). The Pb(2) is also coordinated to a chelating carboxylate and two imidazole N atoms from three different ligand moieties (Pb2−O = 2.565−2.576, Pb2−N = 2.522−2.905 Å). It is also coordinated to an O atom of the NO3¯ anion completing hexacoordination (Pb2−O5 = 2.729 Å) (Figure ). shows the polyhedra generated around two Pb2+ centers with sharing of a corner through hydroxide bridges.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of {[Pb2(DIBA)2(OH)(NO3)]} n , (7)

Structural analysis of 7 shows that there are two crystallographically independent Pb2+ centers: one pentacoordinated Pb(1) and the other, hexacoordinated Pb(2). Pb(1) is coordinated to one chelating carboxylate (Pb1-O = 2.547-2.564 Å) and two imidazoles (Pb1-N = 2.591-2.784 Å) from three different ligand moieties. The fifth coordination site is occupied by a hydroxyl group which acts as a bridge between Pb(1) and Pb(2) (Pb1-OH = 2.183, Pb2-OH = 2.199 Å). The Pb(2) is also coordinated to a chelating carboxylate and two imidazole N atoms from three different ligand moieties (Pb2-O = 2.565-2.576, Pb2-N = 2.522-2.905 Å). It is also coordinated to an O atom of the NO3¯ anion completing hexacoordination (Pb2-O5 = 2.729 Å) (Figure ).  shows the polyhedra generated around two Pb2+ centers with sharing of a corner through hydroxide bridges.

elements.clean_text: 19  Coordination environment around Co ion in 7 and schematic view of the puckered 2D sheet composed by bridging 1D chains through hydroxide ions in 7.

elements.content: An interesting feature of this structure is the propagation of 1D → 2D through hydroxide bridges. The 1D chain extending along the c-axis is composed of Pb2+ metal centers and DIBA¯ bridging ligands. This is further connected with another ladder-like chain through hydroxide bridges to generate a 2D coordination polymer (Figure ). These 2D sheets are stacked in AA fashion and connected with weak CH···π interactions to generate an overall 3D network. To obtain structural systematics with this ligand, a number of metal ions were used for building MOFs, but our attempts were not successful.

elements.content: In order to examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, we carried out TG analysis. Samples were heated up to 700 °C in air at the rate of 5 °C/min. The TGA curve of 1 shows that the weight loss of 3.5% appearing at 90 °C corresponds to the loss of one water molecule (calculated, 3.5%) and the framework is stable up to 310 °C (). Thermogram of 2·H 2 O shows a weight loss of 4.6% corresponding to one water molecule (calculated, 4.8%) at 100 °C and the 2D framework is stable up to 355 °C. Complete decomposition is achieved beyond this temperature. Compound 2 obtained by heating crystals of 2·H 2 O at 100 °C for 2 h under a vacuum in a SC−SC transformation shows no weight loss in its thermogram up to 350 °C (). Thereafter, the compound decomposes. For 3, no weight loss is observed up to ∼300 °C beyond which it decomposes. In comparison, 4 is less stable and its decomposition starts at 270 °C. For 5, a weight loss of 8.5% is observed between 70 and 100 °C corresponding to the loss of three lattice water molecules (calculated, 8.2%). The framework starts to decompose beyond 260 °C (). Compound 6, on the other hand, shows a loss of water molecules gradually up to 210 °C and complete decomposition is achieved beyond 310 °C (). In order to examine the stability of these frameworks, PXRD were measured at their near decomposition temperatures (), which confirms that these polymers maintain overall structural integrity up to the temperatures as indicated in their respective thermograms.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

In order to examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, we carried out TG analysis. Samples were heated up to 700 °C in air at the rate of 5 °C/min. The TGA curve of 1 shows that the weight loss of 3.5% appearing at 90 °C corresponds to the loss of one water molecule (calculated, 3.5%) and the framework is stable up to 310 °C (). Thermogram of 2⋅H  2  O shows a weight loss of 4.6% corresponding to one water molecule (calculated, 4.8%) at 100 °C and the 2D framework is stable up to 355 °C. Complete decomposition is achieved beyond this temperature. Compound 2 obtained by heating crystals of 2⋅H  2  O at 100 °C for 2 h under a vacuum in a SC-SC transformation shows no weight loss in its thermogram up to 350 °C (). Thereafter, the compound decomposes. For 3, no weight loss is observed up to ~300 °C beyond which it decomposes. In comparison, 4 is less stable and its decomposition starts at 270 °C. For 5, a weight loss of 8.5% is observed between 70 and 100 °C corresponding to the loss of three lattice water molecules (calculated, 8.2%). The framework starts to decompose beyond 260 °C (). Compound 6, on the other hand, shows a loss of water molecules gradually up to 210 °C and complete decomposition is achieved beyond 310 °C (). In order to examine the stability of these frameworks, PXRD were measured at their near decomposition temperatures (), which confirms that these polymers maintain overall structural integrity up to the temperatures as indicated in their respective thermograms.

Magnetic Properties

Magnetic data were collected for a crushed microcrystalline sample of 5 at an applied field of 400 G in the 2-300 K temperature range. The data are shown in Figure  as susceptibility and χT vs T plot. The χT product at 300 K has a value of 1.29 cm3 K mol-1, in agreement with the expected value for one Ni2+ ion with S = 1 and g = 2.25.

elements.content: With lowering of temperature, the χT product remains nearly constant until a small increase is observed to a maximum value of 1.42 cm3 K mol−1 at 20 K. Below this temperature, the χT decreases to 0.64 cm3 K mol−1 at 2 K. All these indicate a weak ferromagnetic coupling along the 1D chains of Ni2+ ions in 5, as expected due to the spin-polarization mechanism through a meta-substituted phenylene ring. At temperatures below 20 K, the χT product decreases slowly. This can be attributed to zero-field splitting of the Ni2+ ions and to antiferromagnetic interchain interactions via H-bonds between the coordinated water and the noncoordinated carboxylate group as shown in Figure . The inset of Figure shows the magnetization vs field behavior for 5. The value per Ni2+ ion at 5 T is 1.8 and the curve does not follow the Brillouin function due to single ion anisotropy of Ni2+.

elements.content: For 6, the χT vs T plot is shown in Figure . The χT product at 300 K for 6 has a value of 1.11 cm3 K mol−1 per Co2+ ion, below the expected value for one Co2+ ion with S = 3/2 and g = 2.0 (1.875 cm3 K mol−1). As the temperature decreases so does the χT product to a value of 0.79 cm3 K mol−1 at 30 K due to a combination of antiferromagnetic coupling and the spin−orbit coupling of hexacoordinated Co2+ ion. Below this temperature, the χT product increases to a maximum, which is field dependent, indicating the onset of a state with a net spin. The zero-field cool/field-cool measurements at 20 G applied field show divergence below 4 K (inset of Figure ). The shape of the χT vs T plot with the observed minimum is typical of ferrimagnetic behavior, where antiferromagnetic coupling between spins of different magnitude or a combination of ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic interactions leads to a nonzero spin ground state.

elements.content: The susceptibility for compound 6 follows the Curie−Weiss law above 50 K, with a Curie constant of 1.2 cm3 mol−1 and a Weiss temperature of −25.3 K. A Curie−Weiss plot for 6 is shown in . A simple phenomenological equation that takes into account the spin−orbit coupling of Co2+ ions reported by Rabu and co-workers χT = A exp(−E soc/kT) + B exp(E A/kT) can be used to fit the data in the 30−300 K temperature range to obtain the antiferromagnetic coupling along the chain. In this equation A + B equals the Curie constant, while E soc and E AF are the activation energies corresponding to the spin−orbit coupling and the antiferromagnetic coupling, respectively. The best fitting parameters were A = 0.4, B = 0.8, E soc/k = 83 K, and E AF = 1.83 K with an agreement factor of R = 0.94, and the calculated data are shown in Figure as a solid line. The A and B values are in agreement with the Curie constant obtained from higher temperature data, and E soc/k is in agreement with the values reported in the literature for Co2+ (E soc/k around 100 K). The data between 30 and 2 K have not been included in the fitting due to the interchain interactions, which start to become important and do not allow compound 6 to be modeled as 1D chains in this temperature range.

elements.content: In order to understand the magnetic properties of 6 one takes into account the crystal structure and the arrangement of 1D chains to form a 3D network described before (vide supra, Figure ). The 1,3,5-substitution of the central aromatic ring of the ligand DIBA¯ favors a weak ferromagnetic coupling between the metals it bridges. The strongest magnetic interaction should be the antiferromagnetic coupling along the 1D chains parallel to the a-axis. The ferromagnetic interactions mediated by the tridentate ligand are expected to be a lot weaker but not negligible. Because of the mixture of antiferromagnetic (along the 1D chains, Figure a) and ferromagnetic interactions (through the ligands, in light blue in Figure b) in a triangular network, spin frustration arises and slow relaxation occurs.

The strongest magnetic interaction should be the antiferromagnetic coupling along the 1D chains parallel to the a-axis. The ferromagnetic interactions mediated by the tridentate ligand are expected to be a lot weaker but not negligible. Because of the mixture of antiferromagnetic (along the 1D chains, Figure a) and ferromagnetic interactions (through the ligands, in light blue in Figure b) in a triangular network, spin frustration arises and slow relaxation occurs.

elements.content: A clear out-of-phase (χ′′) signal appears below 8 K as the in-phase (χ′) signal decreases, indicating a slow relaxation process. The frequency dependence of the signal indicates superparamagnetism or spin-glass behavior. Arrhenius equation gives an effective barrier for reversal of the magnetization with U eff = 96 K and a τo = 2−10 s−1. The evaluation of the frequency dependence of the maximum affords a Mydosh parameter of 0.07, too small for a single-chain magnet, and more in agreement with a spin glass. Finally, an Argand plot for 6 is shown in Figure ; the plot is not perfectly semicircular and can be fitted using the Debye model to a relaxation process with a distribution of energy barriers, with a distribution parameter α = 0.5, in agreement with the expected behavior for a spin-glass. This is only to be expected, given the non-negligible interchains interactions along the tridimensional network of 6. Spin glasses are systems whose magnetic moments freeze at low temperature into random orientations without long-range order. It is generally accepted that frustration or disorder is essential. In 6 the frustrated 3D network of corner sharing tetrahedra gives rise to the spin-glass behavior observed.

elements.content: Luminescent compounds are of great current interest because of their various applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent displays. Recently, the luminescent properties of d10 metal containing carboxylate-systems have been investigated, whereas paramagnetic metal ions generally quench the emission. So, the solid-state fluorescent properties of 1, 2·H 2 O, 2, 3, and 4 were investigated at room temperature and are shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

Luminescent compounds are of great current interest because of their various applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent displays. Recently, the luminescent properties of d10 metal containing carboxylate-systems have been investigated, whereas paramagnetic metal ions generally quench the emission. So, the solid-state fluorescent properties of 1, 2⋅H  2  O, 2, 3, and 4 were investigated at room temperature and are shown in Figure .

elements.content: Emission spectra of 1, 2·H 2 0, 2, 3, and 4 (2′ indicate excitation at 288 nm).
elements.clean_text: 25  Emission spectra of 1, 2⋅H  2  0, 2, 3, and 4 (2' indicate excitation at 288 nm).

elements.content: Compounds 2·H 2 O and its dehydrated form 2 exhibit strong emission at room temperature. The emissions of 2·H 2 O observed at 396 nm (λex = 255 nm) and 430 nm (λex = 288 nm) might be attributable to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or intraligand transitions because ligand coordination to the metal center effectively increases rigidity of the ligand and reduces radiationless decay. The dehydrated product 2 shows two emissions at 427 (strong) and 435 nm (weak) on excitation at 260 and 288 nm, respectively. The difference in these two cases may be due to the dynamic nature of the frameworks. Similarly, 1 and 4 on excitation at 260 nm show strong emissions at 426 and 430 nm, while 3 shows emissions at 430 and 488 nm. On excitation at ∼290 nm, 1, 3, and 4 did not give any emission. Interestingly, the emission centering at ∼430 nm is observed in all the compounds, while the emission at ∼490 nm is not well-resolved except 3 (Figure ). These emission bands might be assigned as LMCT/MLCT bands since no emission is observed either for the free DIBAH ligand or its sodium salt under the experimental conditions. Strong luminescence makes these polymers an excellent candidate for potential photoactive materials since they are thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and nonpolar solvents.

elements.content: We have utilized an arene core based tripodal ligand DICN for the synthesis of seven coordination polymers with different metal ions. The in situ generated DIBA¯ ligand under solvothermal conditions has strong ability to bind with metal ions and a tendency to show the flexibility that can generate a variety of 3D structures. The nature of metal ions is the key to synthesize these polymers, even using similar conditions. We have shown a dynamic framework showing sliding of the layers by single crystal studies. Paramagnetic metal ions have given some good results with DIBA¯. Complex 4 is a rare air-stable 3D Cu(I) coordination polymer, 5 is a ferromagnetically coupled material and 6 is an excellent example of a 3D coordination polymer showing spin glass behavior with slow magnetic relaxation and spin frustration. Photoluminescence properties of d10 metal containing systems indicate that it could be a good candidate for luminescent materials. Further studies with DIBA¯ and similar ligands are underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have utilized an arene core based tripodal ligand DICN for the synthesis of seven coordination polymers with different metal ions. The in situ generated DIBA¯ ligand under solvothermal conditions has strong ability to bind with metal ions and a tendency to show the flexibility that can generate a variety of 3D structures. The nature of metal ions is the key to synthesize these polymers, even using similar conditions. We have shown a dynamic framework showing sliding of the layers by single crystal studies. Paramagnetic metal ions have given some good results with DIBA¯. Complex 4 is a rare air-stable 3D Cu(I) coordination polymer, 5 is a ferromagnetically coupled material and 6 is an excellent example of a 3D coordination polymer showing spin glass behavior with slow magnetic relaxation and spin frustration. Photoluminescence properties of d10 metal containing systems indicate that it could be a good candidate for luminescent materials. Further studies with DIBA¯ and similar ligands are underway in our laboratory.

To a solution of imidazole (20 mmol) in dry DMF (10 mL) was added anhydrous K2CO3 (22 mmol) with constant stirring at 100 °C. After 0.5 h, 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile was added at once and the reaction mixture was allowed to stir for 30 h maintaining the temperature at 100 °C. It was then allowed to cool to RT and poured into crushed ice water (150 mL) and the white solid separated was collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with cold water. The white solid was recrystallized from a mixture of DMF-MeOH solution to get the desired product in crystalline form. Yield, ∼60%. A mixture of CdI2 (0.5 mmol), DICN (0.25 mmol), aqueous NH3 (0.1 mL, 30%), EtOH (4 mL), and distilled water (4 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was heated at 180 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Synthesis of {[Zn(DIBA)(NO<sub>3</sub>)]}<italic toggle="yes"> <sub>n</sub> </italic>, (<bold>3</bold>)

Compound 3 was synthesized under acidic conditions instead of using ammonia solution. A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (1.0 mmol), DICN (0.25 mmol), aqueous HNO3 (0.1 mL, 5 N), EtOH (2 mL), and distilled water (4 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was heated at 160 °C for 24 h under autogenous pressure. Synthesis of 3,5-Di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (DICN)

To a solution of imidazole (20 mmol) in dry DMF (10 mL) was added anhydrous K2CO3 (22 mmol) with constant stirring at 100 °C. After 0.5 h, 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile was added at once and the reaction mixture was allowed to stir for 30 h maintaining the temperature at 100 °C. It was then allowed to cool to RT and poured into crushed ice water (150 mL) and the white solid separated was collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with cold water. The white solid was recrystallized from a mixture of DMF-MeOH solution to get the desired product in crystalline form. Yield, ~60%. cln_elements.content:
In order to examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, we carried out TG analysis. Samples were heated up to 700 °C in air at the rate of 5 °C/min. The TGA curve of 1 shows that the weight loss of 3.5% appearing at 90 °C corresponds to the loss of one water molecule (calculated, 3.5%) and the framework is stable up to 310 °C (). Thermogram of 2·H 2 O shows a weight loss of 4.6% corresponding to one water molecule (calculated, 4.8%) at 100 °C and the 2D framework is stable up to 355 °C. Complete decomposition is achieved beyond this temperature. Compound 2 obtained by heating crystals of 2·H 2 O at 100 °C for 2 h under a vacuum in a SC−SC transformation shows no weight loss in its thermogram up to 350 °C (). Thereafter, the compound decomposes. For 3, no weight loss is observed up to ∼300 °C beyond which it decomposes. In comparison, 4 is less stable and its decomposition starts at 270 °C. For 5, a weight loss of 8.5% is observed between 70 and 100 °C corresponding to the loss of three lattice water molecules (calculated, 8.2%). The framework starts to decompose beyond 260 °C (). Compound 6, on the other hand, shows a loss of water molecules gradually up to 210 °C and complete decomposition is achieved beyond 310 °C (). In order to examine the stability of these frameworks, PXRD were measured at their near decomposition temperatures (), which confirms that these polymers maintain overall structural integrity up to the temperatures as indicated in their respective thermograms.

Magnetic Properties

Magnetic data were collected for a crushed microcrystalline sample of 5 at an applied field of 400 G in the 2−300 K temperature range. The data are shown in Figure as susceptibility and χT vs T plot. The χT product at 300 K has a value of 1.29 cm3 K mol−1, in agreement with the expected value for one Ni2+ ion with S = 1 and g = 2.25.

Thermogravimetric Analysis

In order to examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, we carried out TG analysis. Samples were heated up to 700 °C in air at the rate of 5 °C/min. The TGA curve of 1 shows that the weight loss of 3.5% appearing at 90 °C corresponds to the loss of one water molecule (calculated, 3.5%) and the framework is stable up to 310 °C (). Thermogram of 2⋅H  2  O shows a weight loss of 4.6% corresponding to one water molecule (calculated, 4.8%) at 100 °C and the 2D framework is stable up to 355 °C. Complete decomposition is achieved beyond this temperature. Compound 2 obtained by heating crystals of 2⋅H  2  O at 100 °C for 2 h under a vacuum in a SC-SC transformation shows no weight loss in its thermogram up to 350 °C (). Thereafter, the compound decomposes. For 3, no weight loss is observed up to ~300 °C beyond which it decomposes. In comparison, 4 is less stable and its decomposition starts at 270 °C. For 5, a weight loss of 8.5% is observed between 70 and 100 °C corresponding to the loss of three lattice water molecules (calculated, 8.2%). The framework starts to decompose beyond 260 °C (). Compound 6, on the other hand, shows a loss of water molecules gradually up to 210 °C and complete decomposition is achieved beyond 310 °C (). In order to examine the stability of these frameworks, PXRD were measured at their near decomposition temperatures (), which confirms that these polymers maintain overall structural integrity up to the temperatures as indicated in their respective thermograms.

Magnetic Properties

Magnetic data were collected for a crushed microcrystalline sample of 5 at an applied field of 400 G in the 2-300 K temperature range. The data are shown in Figure  as susceptibility and χT vs T plot. The χT product at 300 K has a value of 1.29 cm3 K mol-1, in agreement with the expected value for one Ni2+ ion with S = 1 and g = 2.25.
